thread.title: Misleading Tesco offers are not applied at the till, investigation finds
thread.title_full: Misleading Tesco offers are not applied at the till, investigation finds

author: Sarah Knapton
title: Misleading Tesco offers are not applied at the till, investigation finds
text:
Science Misleading Tesco offers are not applied at the till, investigation finds Two thirds of Tesco stores visited were found to have out-of-date multi-buy offers which were not applied at the checkout Credit: Rui Vieira/PA Wire Sarah Knapton , Science Editor 13 February 2017 • 6:00am 
S hoppers at Britain’s biggest supermarket are being ripped off by out-of-date offers which do not get applied at the till, a BBC investigation has found. 
Tesco has pledged to take immediate action after Inside Out discovered that two thirds of stores visited were still advertising offers after they had expired. 

Reporter Jonathan Gibson found that in some cases multi-buy deals were still being offered months after the deductions were no longer valid. 
Although the supermarket honoured the discount if a shopper noticed it had not been applied, trading standards officials said that it was unknown how many had not checked and could have been left out of pocket. 
“If customer A has come back and complained and been refunded that doesn’t mean there weren’t 20 other customers who didn’t spot it and didn’t complain,” said Martin Fisher from the Chartered Trading Standards Institute. Trading standards officials said many shoppers might not have noticed that the discounts were not given at the till 
T he BBC visited 50 stores across the country and found 33 of them were still advertising expired offers, which were not applied at the checkout. 
Even after reporters pointed out the discrepancies to staff, some stores still failed to remove out-of-date labels on the shelves. In the worst case, staff at a TescoExpress outlet in Birmingham repeatedly failed to remove labels showing produce as on offer when it no longer was for more than month after it was brought to their attention. 
“That is very bad. It’s pretty basic that if one customer has shown something wrong then it’s put right to stop other customers being misled” added Mr Fisher 
Responding to the findings a Tesco Spokesperson said “We take great care to deliver clear and accurate labels for our customers so they can make informed decisions on the products they buy. 
“We are disappointed that errors occurred and will be working with the stores involved to reinforce our responsibilities to our customers”. Supermarkets have previously come under fire from watchdogs for multibuy deals which do not actually save money 
T esco says it will be double checking the accuracy of the price labels at all its stores as a result of the BBC’s investigation. 
The company runs more than 3,500 stores across the UK. 
Last year Tesco was criticised by farming unions for selling meat and fresh produce under made-up British farm names such as ‘Woodside Farms.’ 
The union has lodged a formal complaint with trading standards, claiming that British-sounding farm names mislead consumers into thinking they are buying British produce, when it may be from abroad. 
Meat sold under the "Boswell Farms" and "Woodside Farms" brands was found to come from the Netherlands, Denmark and Ireland. 
The new investigation can be seen on BBC1 at 7.30pm on Monday February 13th and on iplayer for 30 days after. Follow Telegraph Science & Tech
